item.title: What to ask during the interview process
item.description:
• Company goal/mission?
  • Company stage and size?
  • Who’s the CEO (product, sales, engineering?)
  • Technology stack?
  • PTO policy?
  • Tell me more about the company culture?
  • How decisions are made?
  • How new ideas are introduced?
  • How you ensure the quality of your software?
  • How you ensure the security of your software?
  • How you ensure the scalability of your software?
  • How frequent do you ship to production?
  • How is software delivered?
  • How you deal with regressions?
  • How (and how often) do you collect user input and feedback?
  • How are teams organized?
  • How the services are organized?
  • How technical debt is managed?
  • What’s the core hours it’s expected to be online for synchronous collaboration with the team?
  • Is there a performance review process in place? How does it work?
  • How frequent will I get feedback on what I’m doing?
  • How does the company help me learn new things (for example, personal stipend, available online learning platforms, etc)
  • Tell me about a hard decision you had to make recently
  • Tell me about a highlight while working at this company
  • Tell me about a lowlight while working at this company
  • How is support done?
  • How much data driven is the company?

item.title: Learning New Programming Languages
item.description:
A pragmatic programmer must be learning new things, constantly. A new programming language per year is a good average according to the PragProg book. After you decided you’ll learn a new language, the important question is: which language?

Maybe you can start with a language that’s similar to the ones you already know. That’s a good start. But once you’re starting to form this new habit, try learning languages that are weird to you.

More valuable than learning how to solve similar problems using different languages is actually learning about problems you’re not familiar with that these weird languages aim to solve. Expanding your knowledge about approaches and design ideas will help you write better code.

item.title: About Hostnames
item.description:
Giving your machine a good hostname is important. This small gesture demonstrates how much you care about your setup. If you don’t know your hostname, you’ll have a hard time remotely connecting to it. Also, when using tmux, people will have to look at that weird name for a long time.

Have respect for your machine. Give it a good hostname.
